title: zkID.app 指南攻略 - zCloak Network
body:
## 

### 什么是zCloak网络？

zCloak网络是一个保护隐私的计算平台。它实现了一种新的计算模式，人们可以在客户端设备上对他们的数据进行计算/分析，而不是在集中式服务器上。他们的计算的完整性被零知识证明所证明。通过zCloak网络，人们可以使用他们的真实世界的数据，例如，DeFi、身份、生物识别应用，而不需要披露他们的隐私。

### 什么是zkID.app？

**证明你是谁，而不告诉你是谁。**

zkID.app是zCloak网络的第一个产品，用于保护隐私的自我主权身份。它可以在浏览器扩展中对用户身份数据进行本地计算。由一个新颖的密码学原件zk-STARK提供支持，生成零知识证明，以确保用户计算的完整性，并隐藏用户的输入数据。因此，用户可以向任何实体证明他们的身份属性，例如智能合约，而不需要向任何第三方暴露他们的现实生活数据。

### 什么是zkID.app指南？

在zkID.app指南中，将为您的游戏角色生成一个身份凭证，您将收到一个POAP（出席证明协议）NFT作为成功通过指南的纪念。POAP将根据你的身份证明的细节空投到你的MetaMask钱包地址。有趣的是，你永远不会向NFT铸币智能合约展示你的证书数据。相反，你向它发送一个ZK证明，证明你符合某些要求。这就是我们所说的 "证明你是谁而不告诉你是谁 "的意思。

zkID.app指南是一个快速演示，以展示zCloak网络的能力。一个用于更多通用应用程序的抛光用户界面将很快发布。

所以请遵循指南，申请你的POAP NFT!

### zkID.app 指南攻略

准备工作

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*9Q54JehGMoTJET9Z)

进入zkid.app，按照 "连接你的钱包并开始 "的链接开始。连接您的MetaMask钱包，将您的网络切换到 `Moonbase-Alpha`.

[https://zkid.app/](https://zkid.app/)

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1276/0\*Ii0-ZRDR_qW5Zc2m)

一个水龙头会自动分配一些`Moonbase-Alphanet`的DEV代币到你的MetaMask钱包，以便在以后的步骤中支付气体费用。

点击 "开始 "并按照指导步骤操作。

1\. 安装zCloak ID钱包。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*Mo8dr3iZkkVZcjIz)

点击 "安装"，将zCloak ID钱包添加到您的Chrome扩展程序。(目前支持Chrome/Brave浏览器）。

这个钱包用于存储你的证书，进行ZK-计算，并生成STARK证明。

设置一个密码来保护你的钱包数据，并为未来的操作授予权限。

2\. 输入你的凭证。

在点击 "理解 "之前，阅读来自zCloak王国的信件。

在zCloak王国，每个人都拥有一个身份凭证，包括他们的年龄、等级和装备水平。为了获得这样的凭证，你需要在描述自己的页面上填写你的名字和DoB。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*VI4ecvlM4YwLiSMh)

有四个类别的冒险者可以选择，战士、圣骑士、牧师和法师。他们每个人都会产生不同的POAP风格。POAP风格的规则附在最后。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*3rdbSabkm_Zn0_6i)

您的POAP的设备稀有性是由程序随机决定的。你可以多次点击 "随机"，以达到你想要的参数组合。

然后，通过点击提交按钮，你的身份描述将被发送到我们的证明人那里，以获得证明，并将向你颁发身份凭证。

\*注意，在正常的真实世界的使用情况下，你的身份数据将被加密，并被发送到有执照的KYC服务提供商进行真实性检查。在本指南中，我们忽略了这一步骤，只是假设你所填写的一切都是真实的。 反正这只是一个快速游戏。

3\. 将你的凭证导入你的zCloak ID钱包。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*AIcS1sWujs2Ubz3v)

点击 "下载"，在你的下载文件夹中收到一个json文件。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*DO3T8QyL44Bt8EGw)

在你的zCloak ID钱包扩展名上点击 "导入"，上传你刚刚下载的json文件。

4\. 生成并上传你的证明。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1262/0\*0IGvsgk5z8eJ8cPr)

点击 "生成"，并在你的zCloak ID钱包扩展中输入你的密码。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*bX0boNlXRnnYdV9K)

点击 "提交"，将你的证明发送给zCloak智能合约。在你的MetaMask钱包扩展上确认气体费用，并等待你的STARK证明的验证结果回来。

\*在幕后，几个守护者节点将独立进行STARK证明的验证，进行多数投票，并将最终结果写入智能合约。所以这可能需要一些时间。

5）申请一个属于你自己的POAP NFT。

一旦你的证明被成功验证，你就可以申请你的免费POAP。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*ZrzveaODmKQNwaN1)

再次确认向您的地址分发POAP的汽油费。

等待几秒钟，你就可以在你的仪表板上查看你的POAP!

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*4U4bJsCACRiWsO3u)

\*注意：在这整个过程中，你的角色数据从未离开过你。这就是我们所说的 "数据和计算，都要掌握在自己手中 "的意思。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0\*h8bsonqEO4IguraW)

如果你想再次尝试该指南，请点击 "清除存储和重放 "按钮，删除浏览器本地存储中的凭证。(你在zCloak ID钱包扩展中的凭证和证明将在你每次重放指南时被替换成新的凭证）。

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1230/0\*Ecyti7RBIa17NVCg)

改变你连接到zkid.app的MetaMask账户，并重新启动指南。

## Tech Takeaways

This guide demonstrates how we can use zero-knowledge proof for computation in user devices. Technology wise, there are 3 key takeaways:

1. Data and computation are in user space, not in centralized servers.
2. [A WASM zk-STARK virtual machine](https://github.com/maticnetwork/miden) is used for local computation — range checking, membership and more general purpose computations are all supported.
3. [DID](https://www.w3.org/TR/did-core/), [Verifiable Credential](https://www.w3.org/TR/vc-data-model/) (with the support of [KILT protocol](https://www.kilt.io/)) and ZK-proof technology are combined to guarantee the authenticity of user data and the integrity of user computation.

We hope you liked this guide and got your POAP NFT. More use cases are coming for the zkID.app soon. You can follow [zCloak twitter account](https://twitter.com/zCloakNetwork) and join our [discord channel](https://discord.gg/2cxSVTHc) to learn more.

## **\*POAP Style Rules**

POAP的样式因年龄、等级和装备的稀有程度而异。计算规则如下：

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*Mt07JvJdTYI1uEPyltItVg.png)

1. 战士和圣骑士：物理伤害；牧师和法师：魔法伤害
2. 如果一个冒险者是未成年人（年龄小于18岁），那么这个冒险者应该持有盾牌（物理伤害）或魔法书（魔法伤害）。
3. 如果冒险者是成年人，那么冒险者应该持有剑（物理伤害）或魔杖（魔法伤害）。
4. 如果所有装备的平均稀有度超过6，冒险者将获得一个象征其高级装备的金边POAP。

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don’t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: “I fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER”. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let’s examine the reasons: (1) ain’t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‘you’ exist is because your dad’s sperm fertilized your mom’s egg. Somewhere along the way, ‘you’ came into existence. However, the answer to the question “Why did you fall off your bike?” requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously just do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let’s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let’s begin at the moment in which you obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon experiencing reality for the first time, you are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, develop an awareness of your existence (‘consciousness’), achieve control of your thoughts (‘agency’ or ‘creativity’), and eventually learn from your environment (‘intelligence’, ‘cognition’, or as I like to say, ‘an ability to connect the dots’). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‘information’) interpreted as truth (‘knowledge’) and the connections are a model that describes the functional i/o relationships between bits (‘understanding’). It is as if reality is a Turing-Complete system and our brains are the Turing Machine (lol… not an original analogy). Putting this all together, we exist in reality as a conscious, intelligent agent perceiving a series of moments (‘experience’) which we call life. The one thing missing in this analogy is our ‘imagination’ -- the power to “see the unseen”. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is actually inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now … but will definitely discuss it in a future post.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about the past is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration, and trust their observations and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Also, your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- “take nobody’s word for it”. 

An historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it’s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus on its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth … though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying “wisdom of the crowd”. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying “fatality of the mob”. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise, not truth-seeking\*\*\*. There is another common phrase, “history is written by the winners”, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser’s side. This is not all the publisher’s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but this missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias. 

Evidence is a discovery -- a gain of information which completes our understanding and builds our intuition. It is still up to humans to induce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Evidence can indicate the likelihood of a particular events’ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation builds context. It entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase “drawing a conclusion”. Every piece of evidence or account of history has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and imaginative renderings do not prove dinosaurs’ existence. It simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later 'discovers' them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil. 

Evidence is an empirical starting point. We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially history which we did not personally observe (and even when we do observe things … our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, feelings, emotions, and motivation) which we may not be aware of in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). To find the truth, you must first become aware of bias in order to account for its influence during an experience. Bias recognition provides context. With context, you gain perspective and can more accurately determine whether a piece of evidence is circumstantial. At the same time, we will always have missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate account of history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that the world was deterministic because everything can be explained. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don’t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant’s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series which breaks down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that you do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are *First Principles* -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination. 

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‘the seen’ in terms of ‘the unseen’. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom’s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root.

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Explanations have degrees of completeness. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and leaves nothing to chance. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‘justified true belief’ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as true. One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation describes a fundamental truth (a law of nature) because there is always a chance that we discover new knowledge debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

subjective truth <signal> objective truth

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). The goal of knowledge is to find more knowledge.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ezkhilGEtWHvK3R_-xt31.png?height=716&width=1127)

Explanations can retroactively imply causation and also fuel predictions -→ which builds knowledge -→ which inspires imagination -→ which creates explanations. These ‘creations’ brings a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‘you’). Knowledge is not scarce. It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

> “**What I cannot create, I do not understand**”
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It just exists. It is the purest form of objectivity. Frankly, it does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one major exception. The only natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability about the probability distribution of electrons in spacetime. This gets more interesting when you consider spacetime as a series of sequential instances of reality with quantum randomness at the root. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing information gaps. Here are two ways to reduce information gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- using observations to find correlations between hypothesized independent data and the resulting dependent data.

2\.) explanatory methods -- using imagination to create logical arguments describing cause and effect relationships.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem. Empirical methods are useful to identify information gaps. Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you are getting closer to a casual relationship (though there still may be confounding variables or unaccounted factors which are the root cause). However, correlation is not causation …. so … how do you know if your independent factors are truly independent? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Only explanations can generate new knowledge from information not apparent in the observations. An explanation can implicate unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power\*\*\*\*\*\*. At the same time, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information … so get used to it!

If we assume that reality is deterministic, then do we have free will? Can there be a meaning to life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? Can meaning be defined? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding, but rather consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is also true.

\*\*\*\*\*We may get to this at some point.

\*\*\*\*\*\*Explanatory power is the degree to which a factor causes an effect.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It just exists. It is the purest form of objectivity. Frankly, it does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one major exception. The only natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability about the probability distribution of electrons in spacetime. This gets more interesting when you consider spacetime as a series of sequential instances of reality with quantum randomness at the root. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing information gaps. Here are two ways to reduce information gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- using observations to find correlations between hypothesized independent data and the resulting dependent data.

2\.) explanatory methods -- using imagination to create logical arguments describing cause and effect relationships.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem. Empirical methods are useful to identify information gaps. Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you are getting closer to a casual relationship (though there still may be confounding variables or unaccounted factors which are the root cause). However, correlation is not causation …. so … how do you know if your independent factors are truly independent? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Only explanations can generate new knowledge from information not apparent in the observations. An explanation can implicate unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power\*\*\*\*\*\*. At the same time, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information … so get used to it!

If we assume that reality is deterministic, then do we have free will? Can there be a meaning to life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? Can meaning be defined? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding, but rather consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is also true.

\*\*\*\*\*We may get to this at some point.

\*\*\*\*\*\*Explanatory power is the degree to which a factor causes an effect.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

title: Stablecoins: Digital Dollars Demystified
body:
Hey friends 👋

At the time of writing, there are over ten thousand cryptocurrencies listed on **[CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/)**, a popular site for tracking prices. The tokens are listed by market capitalization (coin price multiplied by circulating supply), and the first two are, as expected, Bitcoin and Ethereum. But numbers 3 and 4, as well as many others in the top 100 all have something in common: they’re *stablecoins*.

## What are Stablecoins?

**[Stablecoins](https://ethereum.org/en/stablecoins/)** are basically digital dollars 💵 In simplest terms these are tokens that are **valued 1:1 to a fiat currency; usually the US dollar.** The idea that the coins stay close to their intended value, or *peg,* offers a few distinct features not found in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. Allow me to explain.

Stablecoins offer… well… stability.

You may have noticed that at current inflation rates there is not much incentive to save money in most savings accounts, because the money will lose buying power at a higher percentage per year than the bank will pay you for access to it.

This leads to a market incentive to buy other assets, including stocks, bonds, gold and other rare metals, commodities, real estate etc 💰 This has also lead many to buy Bitcoin (which is programmatically disinflationary) or Ethereum (which uses a burn mechanism called **[EIP-1559](https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/gas/#eip-1559)** to disinflate/deflate supply as network demand increases) with the view that these can function as currencies.

Interestingly though, if a currency is deflationary, there is actually a disincentive to spend it, knowing that by doing so, the thing you buy may never offer equivalent value to what you spent. With that said, that’s not even the biggest worry yet, as institutional and retail speculation against cryptocurrencies has left them in an extended period of **[price discovery](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pricediscovery.asp)**, making them relatively volatile. For as long as this is the case, they unfortunately do not make very good currencies.

But why?

## Stability, my dear Watson

Just like deflation may disincentivize the use of a currency due to the opportunity cost of spending versus saving, volatility, introduces further uncertainty into every transaction. Either the payment I gave you will be worth more than what I received, or the payment you received will be worth less when you go to spend it on something else ⚖️

These are not hypothetical scenarios either. Some businesses do accept Bitcoin, and some people do spend it. In the first **[Crypto Misadventures](https://medium.com/@thumbsupfinance.eth/crypto-misadventures-a-wallet-by-any-other-name-c17fec66d55c)**, I talked about Laszlo Hanyecz whose purchase of two pizzas for 10,000 Bitcoins in 2010 **[would now be worth around $300,000,000](https://bitcoinpizzaindex.net/)** 😳 Laszlo doesn’t regret his decision, but some might. As such, for most people Bitcoin is viewed as a long-term investment; digital gold.

And the same people who might choose to invest in Bitcoin as a store of value might prefer to spend something less volatile, or even — dare I say — *stable.*

Stablecoins allow two parties to transact without worry of sudden shifts in value. They are the most practical form of currency for everyday transactions, cross-border remittances, and for pivoting to and from more volatile assets as a part of regular trading and investing cycles 📈

And importantly, since stablecoins do not fluctuate wildly in price, those living in countries with capital gains taxes on cryptocurrencies can avoid triggering taxable events with every purchase.

Now that we’ve covered the reason for their existence, let’s dive deep on what is undoubtedly the most important question we can ask…

## Where do stablecoins get their value?

As I mentioned at the beginning of this article, there are many popular stablecoins in circulation, each claiming to be pegged to a given reference currency, but what is a peg, and how do these so-called stablecoins maintain that peg? Anyone can say “this coin is worth 1 USD” but unless there’s consensus between every buyer, seller, sender, and receiver that coin is worth 1 USD, the whole thing falls apart. And this has happened on a few occasions, so we definitely want to do our research before converting our greenbacks to digital dollars 🔬

So let’s take a look at exactly what underlies the most popular stablecoins.

## Fiat-collateralized Stablecoins

## Examples: USDC, BUSD, GUSD, TUSD, USDT

The most common way to create a trusted stablecoin is to collateralize each coin 1:1 with actual fiat, held by a trust, ideally in some sort of audited reserve at one or more banks. But that’s not always the way so-called fiat-backed stablecoins work.

You may have heard of **[Tether](https://tether.to/)**, aka USDT. Tether is basically the OG stablecoin, originally launched on the Bitcoin blockchain via the **[Omni protocol](https://www.omnilayer.org/)**. Now ported to basically every major blockchain, Tether enjoys the highest level of acceptance in the DeFi space. However, not everyone trusts Tether.

In 2019, **[the New York Attorney General filed a lawsuit against Tether](https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2019/attorney-general-james-announces-court-order-against-crypto-currency-company)** accusing the company of misappropriating funds. The lawsuit was settled out of court for $18.5M but questions have repeatedly come up about Tether’s use of debt to collateralize their issuance, as well as their inconsistent self-reporting of their offshore reserves.

For this reason, many people prefer to bypass Tether in favour of some of these other other options:

**[USD Coin](https://www.circle.com/en/usdc)**, aka USDC is the second most popular stablecoin by market capitalization. Like Tether, it is fiat-collateralized; unlike Tether it is backed only by USD cash and cash-equivalents, is held in custody in the united states in a fully audited and monitored account, and is redeemable 1:1 for US dollars via Circle’s website, Coinbase, and other exchanges.

**[Binance USD](https://www.binance.com/en/busd)** aka BUSD is the third largest stablecoin in terms of market cap. It is a 1:1 USD-backed stablecoin approved by the **[New York State Department of Finance Services (NYDFS)](https://www.dfs.ny.gov/)**, issued in partnership with Paxos. For those heavily invested in the **[Binance ecosystem](https://medium.com/binanceexchange/the-binance-ecosystem-beyond-the-cryptocurrency-exchange-c91602f8c6f3)**, this is probably going to be the preferred option, even though most other stablecoins have been ported to Binance Chain as well. One of the key features of BUSD is that Binance does not charge a fee to convert from BUSD to USDT, USDC, TUSD, or USDP (Paxos’ other near-indentical stablecoin).

**[Gemini dollar](https://www.gemini.com/dollar)**, aka GUSD is yet another fiat-backed stablecoin to come out of a crypto exchange. Gemini being perhaps the most regulatory compliant and trusted cryptocurrency exchange in North America, their stablecoin is exactly as compliant as you’d expect. Like Binance, Gemini’s coin is approved by the NYDFS, but unlike BUSD and USDC, GUSD reserves include **[FDIC insurance of up to $250,000 per user](https://www.fdic.gov/news/press-releases/2010/pr10161.html).** This is a nice perk, but it hasn’t been enough to get GUSD into the top 100 coins by market cap.

Fiat-backed stable coins are popular, especially amongst users in the United States (and lawmakers), and something like USDC is going to be preferable especially for institutions settling large dollar sums, but this type of coin does suffer from one particular flaw…

## Centralized Risk

Above, I mentioned that Gemini’s USD reserves are insured. Probably the money in your bank account is insured too. Not insured from theft, fraud, or misuse by you or any joint account-holder; insured from the bank itself.

**[FDIC insurance](https://www.fdic.gov/resources/deposit-insurance/)** exists because banks can go out of business. But when they go out of business, what happens to the funds? The answer **[before the 1930s](https://www.history.com/topics/great-depression/bank-run)** was that all your money was gone. And gone it was for many during the great depression. The solution came from Franklin D. Roosevelt with his inauguration of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The FDIC, like the CDIC in Canada, has banks pay a form of insurance on deposits they hold, such that a reasonable amount is protected for every depositor. Here’s an interesting anecdote from the FDIC’s 1998 report: **[A Brief History of Deposit Insurance in the United Sates](https://www.fdic.gov/bank/historical/brief/index.html)**

> *Federal deposit insurance became effective on January 1, 1934, providing depositors with $2,500 in coverage, and by any measure it was an immediate success in restoring public confidence and stability to the banking system. Only nine banks failed in 1934, compared to more than 9,000 in the preceding four years.*

9000! So, the mere existence of deposit insurance helped to provide a tremendous amount of stability to the financial system, to the benefit of many Americans. And yet ironically, trust in financial institutions is at an all-time low. This is due largely in part to the disenfranchisement of many communities, high fees, and scandal after scandal from greedy bankers. Clearly, insurance is not a solution to all of the problems with the current financial system 🏦

This has led many to want to opt out of this system altogether. That is the reason cryptocurrencies exist: to provide financial sovereignty.

Since cryptocurrencies on public blockchains are censorship resistant and immutable, governments and banks can’t control the flow of dollars. This is a laudable goal for those that favour the rights of the individual, and correspondingly, it is the reason for the development of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) like China’s Digital Yuan 😒

CBDCs are inherently problematic, and, if hosted on government controlled blockchains, or worse, non-public databases, would constitute the most problematic overreach imaginable: revokable money, social credit scores, and the ability to exclude people from participation in society entirely. It’s right out of a black mirror episode.

The worry then with fiat-collateralized stablecoins is that the US government may decide they don’t want their CBDCs to have to compete with cryptocurrency stablecoins, and since the reserves are are custodied on US soil, they’re easy targets 🎯

To extrapolate this further, let’s imagine non-governmental stablecoins issued in countries like Russia, China, or Saudi Arabia. In this example, it’s easy for anyone to see that these coins would be at very real risk of government interference.

And risk is the enemy of stability.

## Overcollateralized (Crypto-backed) Stablecoins

## Examples: DAI, LUSD, agEUR

What if anyone in the world could mint their own stablecoin? This was the question that **[MakerDAO](https://makerdao.com/en/)** was seeking to answer with the creation of the Dai Stablecoin.

Maker allows users to deposit Ether into a vault to create an overcollateralized loan against which DAI is minted and borrowed. This overcollateralization allows Maker to ensure that DAI can hold its peg even through wild swings. In March of 2020, as a global pandemic was declared, extraordinary market volatility caused a deleveraging spiral that allowed DAI to briefly reach $1.11 briefly and caused liquidation for a number of users. MakerDAO responded quickly with changes to how the protocol handles liquidations and with the new Multi-Collateral Dai (MCD) system which allows for collateral supply of other cryptocurrencies, including other stablecoins.

Because DAI is minted by a smart-contract, the risk of interference by outside parties is very low and even changes to the protocol, like which cryptocurrencies can be accepted as collateral, are governed in a decentralized way. MakerDAO, is as its name suggests, a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) and holders of the MKR token must vote on any proposed changes.

Let’s look at the strengths and weaknesses of DAI, which can be mostly be extrapolated to other overcollateralized stablecoins.

## Benefits of Dai

* **Can be minted by anyone, anywhere, without opening accounts or doing** **[KYC](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/k/knowyourclient.asp)**. We take it for granted in North America, but in many parts of the world anonymous access to cryptocurrency could be the only option to avoid persecution by oppressive governments, cartels, or extremist groups.
* **Your collateral, not theirs**. Unlike fiat-backed stablecoins, you don’t rely on a centralized holder of the currency. In the case of Gemini for example, you buy GUSD, then they deposit an equivalent amount in a bank account, and that bank holds it until such time that you sell GUSD back to Gemini. That level of abstraction (or “middlemen”) is what peer-to-peer cryptocurrencies and Decentralized Finance (DeFi) aim to eliminate. Dai is created through a smart contract. Your loan is not held by individuals at MakerDAO, it is held in a protocol on the blockchain.
* **Dai is infinite**. Because you’re not worrying about exceeding the FDIC insurance cap, or trading dollars 1:1, you can create as much Dai as you want. And one day if the reserve currency of the world is no longer the US dollar, a stablecoin that pegs to something else (like what **[RAI](https://reflexer.finance/)** is trying to do) would be able to operate in the same way.

## Weaknesses of Dai

* **Dai is not 1:1 collateralized**. As I mentioned above, Dai is minted via an overcollateralized loan. This means that unlike USDC for example where you spent $1 (USD) and get 1 USDC, with Dai, you will technically be putting in more collateral, than the value of what you get out. Of course you can get back your collateral by repaying the loan. In fact some use this as a way to borrow stable assets against their Ether to *go long*. You can also trade something else for DAI and the collateral level won’t affect you, outside of itss role in securing the value of the token.
* **Deleveraging risk**. Although the protocol has been changed to dramatically reduce the risk of a deleveraging spiral like the one from March of 2020, the risk is not entirely eliminated. Those who prefer a 1:1 collateral ratio (based on fiat which is less volatile), may prefer to opt for fiat-backed stablecoins.
* **Multi-collateral Dai can be backed by other, more centralized stablecoins**. Some users prefer to reduce their risk of liquidation when minting DAI by using other stablecoins, like USDC. At one time over 50% of MCD backing was made up of USDC, creating a centralized risk vector, though it has since **[shifted back towards a backing of predominantly Ether](https://decrypt.co/84958/ethereum-primary-collateral-decentralized-stablecoin-dai)**. In any case, decentralization purists, may take issue with this.
* **Dai is not the most popular stablecoin**. Due in large part to institutional adoption of USDC and the popularity of Tether outside of the United States, the market capitalization (at the time of writing) of Dai is about 10 times less than that of USDC, and about 12 times less than USDT. This might lead some to choose not to invest in Dai, resulting in lesser demand. In the world of DeFi where much of the returns are based on trading fees or loan interest, demand is key to maximizing returns.

There is at least one place to get great rates on DAI though, and that’s on Notional Finance. Notional is actually the sponsor of this post, but that’s not all. They are also an innovative DeFi platform for earning stable returns when lending, and locking in stable rates when borrowing 🙌

Notional allows lending and borrowing of four assets. Ether, Wrapped Bitcoin, USDC, and DAI. So if you’re looking for a way to earn yield on your stablecoins, look no further!

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*5e_1XdeudtKfGXjVW1t-GQ.jpeg)

## Undercollateralized Stablecoins

## Examples: UST, BAC, USDD

Imagine a stable, currency-pegged token, that was bankless like Dai, but didn’t require overcollateralization. Sounds too good to be true, right? Well, so far, it has been. Every so-called algorithmic stablecoin thus far has had its own controversy and chaos. In the second issue of **[Crypto Misadventures,](https://www.buymeacoffee.com/thumbsupfinance/crypto-misadventures-2)** I talked about how I got rekt taking a gamble on Iron Finance’s vision of an algorithmic stablecoin. In retrospect though, Iron’s approach had pretty obvious flaws that **[neither I, nor Mark Cuban took the time to study](https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/mark-cuban-says-he-lost-money-trading-defi-token-titan-that-crashed-to-zero-2021-6-1030533245?op=1)** 🙈

Since then we’ve seen an even bigger meltdown in the Terra ecosystem. Terra was an EVM compatible blockchain that used a symbiotic relationship between the platform native token, LUNA, and a family of stablecoins, the most prominent of which was a US dollar-pegged token called UST.

Using a system very similar to the one employed by failed projects Iron Finance and Basis Cash, Terra tried to create a stablecoin where rather than backing the coin, a process of seignorage is employed. How this works is that when UST goes above the $1 peg, the protocol incentivizes users to burn LUNA and mint UST. When UST goes below the $1 peg, the protocol incentivizes users to burn UST and mint LUNA.

The problem of course is that when both assets fall in tandem the only solution in the protocol is to rapidly inflate LUNA to be able to burn enough to bring UST back towards its peg. If there is no demand for UST, because people are jumping ship as the price collapses, both tokens can easily go to zero.

And that’s exactly what happened. Both LUNA and UST lost so much value that the only remaining option was to fork the blockchain, and create new ecosystem in which the algorithmic stablecoins were no longer a feature.

Now, we’re seeing this exact model being proposed once again with USDD on the Tron blockchain and given how little difference there is between this project and Terra, it’s probably best to sit this one out.

## Novel Approaches to Decentralized Stablecoins

The most compelling argument for stablecoin experimentation is the same one used for cryptocurrency in general: the potential benefits of reducing the influence and centralized risk brought by institutions. Stability being the goal, it makes sense that some want to feel confident that corrupt motives and perverse incentives are unable to play a role in value of a given token.

With that spirit of experimentation in mind, let’s take a look at a few novel approaches. The inclusion of these tokens is for educational purposes only and should not be seen as an endorsement of their safety as investment vehicles or currencies. Do your own follow up research, and invest your money according to your own risk tolerance.

## FRAX — Fractional-Reserve Algorithmic Stablecoin

Frax gets its name from the fractional-aglorithmic stability mechanism it employs. This novel approach shifts the ratio of collateralization algorithmically according to the market’s pricing of the FRAX token. If FRAX is trading at above $1, the protocol decreases the collateral ratio. If FRAX is trading at under $1, the protocol increases the collateral ratio.

The idea here is actually based on the design of collateralized stablecoins. If we assume that the market only has confidence in a token because they believe it is redeemable for $1 of value, then logically, why not back it accordingly? Adding collateral increases confidence during times of doubt and reducing collateral decreases confidence at times when the market has started to overvalue or speculate against the token.

Currently, the only accepted collateral for FRAX is USDC, which on one hand reduces risk of volatility, but on the other hand, introduces sufficient counterparty risk.

## AMPL / SPOT — Elastic Supply Rebasing Token

**[Ampleforth](https://www.ampleforth.org/basics/)** is not a stablecoin. Instead it is a rebasing token that aims to maintain a peg over long periods (while being volatile over short periods) through a novel mechanism of **supply elasticity**.

Essentially the protocol inflates or deflates supply every single day algorithmically to ensure stable value. Interestingly, and perhaps most importantly, it is *non-dilutive*, which means you are not buying a number of coins, but rather a percentage of the total. This means, as the supply shifts, your balance shifts to help the currency return to its peg.

While stablecoins aim to maintain a peg to the **current** **value** of the US dollar (or whatever fiat currency they’re pegged to), Ampleforth is now, and will (theoretically) be forever pegged to the value of the 2019 US dollar. Making this, ideally, a truly stable currency, even free from the affects of monetary inflation or deflation.

Due to the volatility that AMPL sees on the short term, it’s not ideal for spending, but Ampleforth does intend to introduce a stablecoin of sorts, called SPOT, which will be backed by AMPL. Given the long term stable properties of AMPL, it should be a suitable backing for such a token, which will be nearly identicaly only without the short term supply volatility and rebasing qualities.

That said, neither AMPL nor SPOT are intended to be stablecoins in the way USDC, DAI, or even FRAX are. Like Reflexer’s RAI token (basically single collateral DAI without a peg), these novel tokens aim to hold a stable value over time, without correlating to the current value of a given currency. The idea here is freedom from the monetary policies of central banks, without the volatility of assets like Bitcoin or Ether.

All of this is experimental. There are a lot of great minds working on projects like AMPL and RAI, but they are operating in entirely new territory. Whether or not you feel comfortable participating in these experiments on the future of finance will depend on your risk tolerance. But to say the least, it’s worth knowing that they exist.

## Conclusion

Stablecoins serve many of the same functions as fiat currencies, but within the framework of self-sovereign finance, free from banks, borders, and middlemen. By merely existing on open-source, permissionless blockchains, they offer access to stable currencies to the unbanked, and give the already banked a way to move away from traditional finance (TradFi) to more open, transparent, and equitable systems 👏

By simply moving from US dollars to USDC, you can go from earning 0.01% on your savings account at the bank, to earning a fixed rate hundreds of times that (4.65% at the time of writing) on Notional Finance. And that’s just one of the many options for what you can do with your money when you have complete sovereignty over it.

I hope I’ve opened your eyes to the benefits of stablecoins and, most importantly, I hope I’ve helped demystify what they are and how the various digital currencies differ from each other. Whether or not you choose to own stablecoins as well as which stablecoins you prefer is going to depend on your risk tolerance, your financial approach, and even your theses around things like decentralization and US monetary policy.

As always, go off and do your own research 🤝

And until next time 👋 
 Thumbs Up

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don’t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: “I fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER”. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let’s examine the reasons: (1) ain’t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‘you’ exist is because your dad’s sperm fertilized your mom’s egg. Somewhere along the way, ‘you’ came into existence. However, the answer to the question “Why did you fall off your bike?” requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously just do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let’s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let’s begin at the moment in which you obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon experiencing reality for the first time, you are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, develop an awareness of your existence (‘consciousness’), achieve control of your thoughts (‘agency’ or ‘creativity’), and eventually learn from your environment (‘intelligence’, ‘cognition’, or as I like to say, ‘an ability to connect the dots’). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‘information’) interpreted as truth (‘knowledge’) and the connections are a model that describes the functional i/o relationships between bits (‘understanding’). It is as if reality is a Turing-Complete system and our brains are the Turing Machine (lol… not an original analogy). Putting this all together, we exist in reality as a conscious, intelligent agent perceiving a series of moments (‘experience’) which we call life. The one thing missing in this analogy is our ‘imagination’ -- the power to “see the unseen”. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is actually inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now … but will definitely discuss it in a future post.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about the past is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration, and trust their observations and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Also, your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- “take nobody’s word for it”. 

An historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it’s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus on its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth … though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying “wisdom of the crowd”. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying “fatality of the mob”. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise, not truth-seeking\*\*\*. There is another common phrase, “history is written by the winners”, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser’s side. This is not all the publisher’s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but this missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias. 

Evidence is a discovery -- a gain of information which completes our understanding and builds our intuition. It is still up to humans to induce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Evidence can indicate the likelihood of a particular events’ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation builds context. It entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase “drawing a conclusion”. Every piece of evidence or account of history has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and imaginative renderings do not prove dinosaurs’ existence. It simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later 'discovers' them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil. 

Evidence is an empirical starting point. We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially history which we did not personally observe (and even when we do observe things … our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, feelings, emotions, and motivation) which we may not be aware of in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). To find the truth, you must first become aware of bias in order to account for its influence during an experience. Bias recognition provides context. With context, you gain perspective and can more accurately determine whether a piece of evidence is circumstantial. At the same time, we will always have missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate account of history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that the world was deterministic because everything can be explained. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don’t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant’s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series which breaks down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that you do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are *First Principles* -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination. 

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‘the seen’ in terms of ‘the unseen’. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom’s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root.

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Explanations have degrees of completeness. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and leaves nothing to chance. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‘justified true belief’ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as true. One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation describes a fundamental truth (a law of nature) because there is always a chance that we discover new knowledge debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). The goal of knowledge is to find more knowledge.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retroactively imply causation and also fuel predictions -→ which builds knowledge -→ which inspires imagination -→ which creates explanations. These ‘creations’ brings a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‘you’). Knowledge is not scarce. It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

> “**What I cannot create, I do not understand**”
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It just exists. It is the purest form of objectivity. Frankly, it does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one major exception. The only natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability about the probability distribution of electrons in spacetime. This gets more interesting when you consider spacetime as a series of sequential instances of reality with quantum randomness at the root. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing information gaps. Here are two ways to reduce information gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- using observations to find correlations between hypothesized independent data and the resulting dependent data.

2\.) explanatory methods -- using imagination to create logical arguments describing cause and effect relationships.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem. Empirical methods are useful to identify information gaps. Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you are getting closer to a casual relationship (though there still may be confounding variables or unaccounted factors which are the root cause). However, correlation is not causation …. so … how do you know if your independent factors are truly independent? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Only explanations can generate new knowledge from information not apparent in the observations. An explanation can implicate unknown factor as the root cause.

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire knowledge. Lean on *First Principles* thinking. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power\*\*\*\*\*\*. At the same time, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information … so get used to it!

If we assume that reality is deterministic, then do we have free will? Can there be a meaning to life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? Can meaning be defined? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding, but rather consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is also true.

\*\*\*\*\*We may get to this at some point.

\*\*\*\*\*\*Explanatory power is the degree to which a factor causes an effect.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

title: Stablecoins: Digital Dollars Demystified
body:
Hey friends 👋

At the time of writing, there are over ten thousand cryptocurrencies listed on **[CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/)**, a popular site for tracking prices. The tokens are listed by market capitalization (coin price multiplied by circulating supply), and the first two are, as expected, Bitcoin and Ethereum. But numbers 3 and 4, as well as many others in the top 100 all have something in common: they’re *stablecoins*.

## What are Stablecoins?

**[Stablecoins](https://ethereum.org/en/stablecoins/)** are basically digital dollars 💵 In simplest terms these are tokens that are **valued 1:1 to a fiat currency; usually the US dollar.** The idea that the coins stay close to their intended value, or *peg,* offers a few distinct features not found in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. Allow me to explain.

Stablecoins offer… well… stability.

You may have noticed that at current inflation rates there is not much incentive to save money in most savings accounts, because the money will lose buying power at a higher percentage per year than the bank will pay you for access to it.

This leads to a market incentive to buy other assets, including stocks, bonds, gold and other rare metals, commodities, real estate etc 💰 This has also lead many to buy Bitcoin (which is programmatically disinflationary) or Ethereum (which uses a burn mechanism called **[EIP-1559](https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/gas/#eip-1559)** to disinflate/deflate supply as network demand increases) with the view that these can function as currencies.

Interestingly though, if a currency is deflationary, there is actually a disincentive to spend it, knowing that by doing so, the thing you buy may never offer equivalent value to what you spent. With that said, that’s not even the biggest worry yet, as institutional and retail speculation against cryptocurrencies has left them in an extended period of **[price discovery](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pricediscovery.asp)**, making them relatively volatile. For as long as this is the case, they unfortunately do not make very good currencies.

But why?

## Stability, my dear Watson

Just like deflation may disincentivize the use of a currency due to the opportunity cost of spending versus saving, volatility, introduces further uncertainty into every transaction. Either the payment I gave you will be worth more than what I received, or the payment you received will be worth less when you go to spend it on something else ⚖️

These are not hypothetical scenarios either. Some businesses do accept Bitcoin, and some people do spend it. In the first **[Crypto Misadventures](https://mirror.xyz/thumbsupfinance.eth/NlzptJn4BKk3-yFw1EZsSufgg_fbBHEYIdjTPK9e-8I)**, I talked about Laszlo Hanyecz whose purchase of two pizzas for 10,000 Bitcoins in 2010 **[would now be worth around $300,000,000](https://bitcoinpizzaindex.net/)** 😳 Laszlo doesn’t regret his decision, but some might. As such, for most people Bitcoin is viewed as a long-term investment; digital gold.

And the same people who might choose to invest in Bitcoin as a store of value might prefer to spend something less volatile, or even — dare I say — *stable.*

Stablecoins allow two parties to transact without worry of sudden shifts in value. They are the most practical form of currency for everyday transactions, cross-border remittances, and for pivoting to and from more volatile assets as a part of regular trading and investing cycles 📈

And importantly, since stablecoins do not fluctuate wildly in price, those living in countries with capital gains taxes on cryptocurrencies can avoid triggering taxable events with every purchase.

Now that we’ve covered the reason for their existence, let’s dive deep on what is undoubtedly the most important question we can ask…

## Where do stablecoins get their value?

As I mentioned at the beginning of this article, there are many popular stablecoins in circulation, each claiming to be pegged to a given reference currency, but what is a peg, and how do these so-called stablecoins maintain that peg? Anyone can say “this coin is worth 1 USD” but unless there’s consensus between every buyer, seller, sender, and receiver that coin is worth 1 USD, the whole thing falls apart. And this has happened on a few occasions, so we definitely want to do our research before converting our greenbacks to digital dollars 🔬

So let’s take a look at exactly what underlies the most popular stablecoins.

## Fiat-collateralized Stablecoins

## Examples: USDC, BUSD, GUSD, TUSD, USDT

The most common way to create a trusted stablecoin is to collateralize each coin 1:1 with actual fiat, held by a trust, ideally in some sort of audited reserve at one or more banks. But that’s not always the way so-called fiat-backed stablecoins work.

You may have heard of **[Tether](https://tether.to/)**, aka USDT. Tether is basically the OG stablecoin, originally launched on the Bitcoin blockchain via the **[Omni protocol](https://www.omnilayer.org/)**. Now ported to basically every major blockchain, Tether enjoys the highest level of acceptance in the DeFi space. However, not everyone trusts Tether.

In 2019, **[the New York Attorney General filed a lawsuit against Tether](https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2019/attorney-general-james-announces-court-order-against-crypto-currency-company)** accusing the company of misappropriating funds. The lawsuit was settled out of court for $18.5M but questions have repeatedly come up about Tether’s use of debt to collateralize their issuance, as well as their inconsistent self-reporting of their offshore reserves.

For this reason, many people prefer to bypass Tether in favour of some of these other other options:

**[USD Coin](https://www.circle.com/en/usdc)**, aka USDC is the second most popular stablecoin by market capitalization. Like Tether, it is fiat-collateralized; unlike Tether it is backed only by USD cash and cash-equivalents, is held in custody in the united states in a fully audited and monitored account, and is redeemable 1:1 for US dollars via Circle’s website, Coinbase, and other exchanges.

**[Binance USD](https://www.binance.com/en/busd)** aka BUSD is the third largest stablecoin in terms of market cap. It is a 1:1 USD-backed stablecoin approved by the **[New York State Department of Finance Services (NYDFS)](https://www.dfs.ny.gov/)**, issued in partnership with Paxos. For those heavily invested in the **[Binance ecosystem](https://medium.com/binanceexchange/the-binance-ecosystem-beyond-the-cryptocurrency-exchange-c91602f8c6f3)**, this is probably going to be the preferred option, even though most other stablecoins have been ported to Binance Chain as well. One of the key features of BUSD is that Binance does not charge a fee to convert from BUSD to USDT, USDC, TUSD, or USDP (Paxos’ other near-indentical stablecoin).

**[Gemini dollar](https://www.gemini.com/dollar)**, aka GUSD is yet another fiat-backed stablecoin to come out of a crypto exchange. Gemini being perhaps the most regulatory compliant and trusted cryptocurrency exchange in North America, their stablecoin is exactly as compliant as you’d expect. Like Binance, Gemini’s coin is approved by the NYDFS, but unlike BUSD and USDC, GUSD reserves include **[FDIC insurance of up to $250,000 per user](https://www.fdic.gov/news/press-releases/2010/pr10161.html).** This is a nice perk, but it hasn’t been enough to get GUSD into the top 100 coins by market cap.

Fiat-backed stable coins are popular, especially amongst users in the United States (and lawmakers), and something like USDC is going to be preferable especially for institutions settling large dollar sums, but this type of coin does suffer from one particular flaw…

## Centralized Risk

Above, I mentioned that Gemini’s USD reserves are insured. Probably the money in your bank account is insured too. Not insured from theft, fraud, or misuse by you or any joint account-holder; insured from the bank itself.

**[FDIC insurance](https://www.fdic.gov/resources/deposit-insurance/)** exists because banks can go out of business. But when they go out of business, what happens to the funds? The answer **[before the 1930s](https://www.history.com/topics/great-depression/bank-run)** was that all your money was gone. And gone it was for many during the great depression. The solution came from Franklin D. Roosevelt with his inauguration of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The FDIC, like the CDIC in Canada, has banks pay a form of insurance on deposits they hold, such that a reasonable amount is protected for every depositor. Here’s an interesting anecdote from the FDIC’s 1998 report: **[A Brief History of Deposit Insurance in the United Sates](https://www.fdic.gov/bank/historical/brief/index.html)**

> *Federal deposit insurance became effective on January 1, 1934, providing depositors with $2,500 in coverage, and by any measure it was an immediate success in restoring public confidence and stability to the banking system. Only nine banks failed in 1934, compared to more than 9,000 in the preceding four years.*

9000! So, the mere existence of deposit insurance helped to provide a tremendous amount of stability to the financial system, to the benefit of many Americans. And yet ironically, trust in financial institutions is at an all-time low. This is due largely in part to the disenfranchisement of many communities, high fees, and scandal after scandal from greedy bankers. Clearly, insurance is not a solution to all of the problems with the current financial system 🏦

This has led many to want to opt out of this system altogether. That is the reason cryptocurrencies exist: to provide financial sovereignty.

Since cryptocurrencies on public blockchains are censorship resistant and immutable, governments and banks can’t control the flow of dollars. This is a laudable goal for those that favour the rights of the individual, and correspondingly, it is the reason for the development of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) like China’s Digital Yuan 😒

CBDCs are inherently problematic, and, if hosted on government controlled blockchains, or worse, non-public databases, would constitute the most problematic overreach imaginable: revokable money, social credit scores, and the ability to exclude people from participation in society entirely. It’s right out of a black mirror episode.

The worry then with fiat-collateralized stablecoins is that the US government may decide they don’t want their CBDCs to have to compete with cryptocurrency stablecoins, and since the reserves are are custodied on US soil, they’re easy targets 🎯

To extrapolate this further, let’s imagine non-governmental stablecoins issued in countries like Russia, China, or Saudi Arabia. In this example, it’s easy for anyone to see that these coins would be at very real risk of government interference.

And risk is the enemy of stability.

## Overcollateralized (Crypto-backed) Stablecoins

## Examples: DAI, LUSD, agEUR

What if anyone in the world could mint their own stablecoin? This was the question that **[MakerDAO](https://makerdao.com/en/)** was seeking to answer with the creation of the Dai Stablecoin.

Maker allows users to deposit Ether into a vault to create an overcollateralized loan against which DAI is minted and borrowed. This overcollateralization allows Maker to ensure that DAI can hold its peg even through wild swings. In March of 2020, as a global pandemic was declared, extraordinary market volatility caused a deleveraging spiral that allowed DAI to briefly reach $1.11 briefly and caused liquidation for a number of users. MakerDAO responded quickly with changes to how the protocol handles liquidations and with the new Multi-Collateral Dai (MCD) system which allows for collateral supply of other cryptocurrencies, including other stablecoins.

Because DAI is minted by a smart-contract, the risk of interference by outside parties is very low and even changes to the protocol, like which cryptocurrencies can be accepted as collateral, are governed in a decentralized way. MakerDAO, is as its name suggests, a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) and holders of the MKR token must vote on any proposed changes.

Let’s look at the strengths and weaknesses of DAI, which can be mostly be extrapolated to other overcollateralized stablecoins.

## Benefits of Dai
